characteristic finding of Shogun Syndrome.
You should know this term lymphocytic siallidinitis because that's a buzzword for the USMLE.
Many patients have primary Shogun Syndrome where they just have Shogun Syndrome by itself.
However it also occurs secondary to other autoimmune conditions.
For example many patients with rheumatoid arthritis and lupus will have their condition complicated
by the development of Shogun Syndrome on top of their other autoimmune disorder.
And then a disorder where it's particularly high yield to know about Shogun Syndrome is
primary biliary cirrhosis.
This is a disorder where there's autoimmune destruction of the bile ducts and almost
half of these patients are sometimes more than half can develop Shogun Syndrome symptoms.
There are four antibody tests that are relevant to the diagnosis of Shogun Syndrome.
The first one is the anti-nuclear antibody test or the ANA.
You may know that this test is abnormal in lupus and many other autoimmune disorders.
So when it's abnormal it's not specific for Shogun Syndrome.
However a negative result makes Shogun Syndrome less likely.
The second antibody test is the rheumatoid factor.
This is positive and rheumatoid arthritis but it is also elevated in patients who have
Shogun Syndrome.
Interestingly it can be elevated in patients who have primary Shogun Syndrome as well as
in those who have Shogun Syndrome secondary to rheumatoid arthritis.
And then the final two antibodies are the SS antibodies.
The first one is anti-SSA or the Rho antibody and the second one is anti-SSB or the LAW
antibody.
Both of these are abnormal in patients who have Shogun Syndrome and in fact the SS stands
for Shogun Syndrome.
And as you will see later elevated levels of these antibodies in Shogun Syndrome or otherwise
are associated with the development of neonatal lupus.
To make the diagnosis of Shogun Syndrome you can also measure tear and saliva production.
The way tear production is measured is through something called the Schirmer test.
This test reflects tear production.
Filter paper is placed near the lower eyelid of the patient as if shown in the drawing
on the screen and then the patient closes their eyes and you measure the amount of
wetting on the filter paper that occurs over five minutes.
You can also test the function of the salivary glands clinically.
The first way to do this is with salivary glands' centigraphy.
This is a nuclear medicine test where you administer a radio tracer and you look at the
uptake of that radio tracer by the salivary glands.
If the salivary glands have been destroyed by an autoimmune process there will be a low
uptake of the radio tracer and this is what you see in patients who have Shogun Syndrome.
The other way to test the salivary glands is to literally measure the amount of spit that
the patient can produce.
This is called silometry.
In this case you ask the patient to collect all the saliva they can produce over 15 minutes
and then you weigh the sample.
You can make the diagnosis of Shogun Syndrome if you have any four of the six criteria I've
listed on the screen here present in a patient.
So first of all you need typical Shogun Syndrome symptoms in the eyes and in the mouth.
Also you need some objective evidence of those signs that they're coming from decreased
tear and saliva production.
So objective evidence of the ocular signs include the Schirmer test like I showed you
before.
And objective evidence of the oral signs include salivary testing like I showed you before.
And then finally another criteria is a biopsy result showing lymphocytic sialidinitis
as I discussed before and then the last criteria are the SS antibody tests.
Importantly the four criteria you use to make the diagnosis must include either histopathology
or the autoantibodies.
You can't have just symptoms and signs.
And the reason for this is because as I told you before some elderly patients will develop
sick of symptoms but they are not due to Shogun Syndrome.
Those patients won't have abnormal biopsy results or abnormal antibody tests.
And then there are also a number of systemic diseases like amyloidosis that can cause these
types of signs and symptoms but those patients won't have the abnormal biopsy of Shogun
or the antibody tests.
So you can't have just signs and symptoms.
You also need some of this objective data that supports the diagnosis of Shogun's disease.
One of the most important things for Shogun Syndrome patients to do in order to take good
care of themselves is to have good oral hygiene.
They need to brush their teeth regularly and they need to go to the dentist because as I
told you before without good saliva flow you get a high risk of cavities and serious
periodontal disease.
There are artificial saliva that are available.
You can also treat these patients with the muscarinic agonist pylocarpine.
I talk about this in the neurology modules but this stimulates muscarinic acetylcholine
receptors and that will increase the flow of fluid from the salivary glands and the lacrimal
ducts.
And then finally sometimes steroids are used for the extra glandular manifestations of
the disease, although usually not for the eye and mouth problems.
One of the serious complications of the chronic inflammation of glandular tissue that occurs
in Shogun's disease is B cell lymphoma.
There's an increased risk among Shogun's patients, about 5 to 10% of all patients eventually
develop a lymphoma.
And the classic way for this to present that you should know for your boards is as persistent
unilateral swelling in a gland.
And this may mimic past swelling so the patient may think they're just having a flare
of their Shogun syndrome with a swollen gland in their mouth but in fact it persists and
is much bigger than in the past.
That swollen gland may in fact be a B cell lymphoma.
Like all autoimmune diseases, Shogun syndrome is more common among women and if women with
Shogun syndrome get pregnant, there is a risk that their baby will develop a condition
called neonatal lupus.
Neonatal lupus occurs when maternal antibodies cross the placenta and affect the fetus
and it occurs in about 1 to 2% of babies born to mothers who have an autoimmune condition.
One of the autoimmune conditions that leads to neonatal lupus is systemic lupus erythematosis.
This is where the disease gets its name from.
However, mothers who have Shogun's can also have babies with neonatal lupus.
And it turns out that the antibodies that place the fetus at greatest risk for neonatal
lupus are the SSA and SSB antibodies.
These antibodies can be abnormal in Shogun's disease as we have discussed but they can
also be abnormal in women who have lupus.
And if women have lupus and these two antibody levels are elevated then their baby is at
risk for developing neonatal lupus.
The symptoms of neonatal lupus occur at birth or in the first few weeks of life.
The first symptom and usually what's most noticeable is the rash.
This is not the typical rash that you may know from adult lupus.
This is a different type of rash.
There are multiple red circle of lesions that occur on the face and on the scalp.
This usually resolves in a few weeks.
The thing that is the greatest danger to the baby is congenital, complete heart block.
This is an EKG of complete heart block on the screen here.
And baby is born with congenital, complete heart block from neonatal lupus.
We'll have a very slow heart rate usually in the 50s.
This often does not respond to steroids and unfortunately the baby is often going to
need to have a pacemaker implanted which they will have for the rest of their life.
And that concludes our module on Shogun's Syndrome.
